posts.name: Peyton Harris
posts.cooked: My team is working on swerve using SDS mk3 swerve modules and the sds sample code and sdsib for programming. The readme has instructions on how to set module offsets. The robot drives well at first but seems to get more and more off after just a few minutes. Currently our solution to this would be redoing the module offsets after every match. We are wondering if there might be a better solution to prevent the modules from getting off so quickly.

posts.name: Lexeo
posts.cooked:
How are your magnets seated into the modules? Did you use appropriate retention compound?

If not, you should.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor

posts.name: Peyton Harris
posts.cooked:
I’m not sure what we are using for the retention compound but we’ll check if the magnets are properly seated ASAP.

Thank you for your assistance.

posts.name: Lexeo
posts.cooked:
This may be helpful.

If you can remove the encoder magnet easily, it’s not properly retained

posts.name: icemannie
posts.cooked: Gear ratio correct? Any mechanical slippage? CanCoder light green?

posts.name: Josh Buker
posts.cooked: I remember our team had the same issue. We had forgotten to glue down the CANCoder magnet with superglue. That is the retention compound mentioned above. After doing that our gyro drift stopped and it was smooth sailing afterwards.

posts.name: Harrison Shipp
posts.cooked: Thanks everyone, the magnets were not glued and it is looking much better!
